results.title: Angel at my table: a trilogy [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Hibiscus Films, Bridget Ikin and Jane Campion
results.brief_description: This trilogy re-creates the life of New Zealand’s prize winning author Janet Frame, based on her visions of herself and her times. The first part, ‘To the Is-Land’, deals with Janet’s childhood in Oamaru in the 1930’s. Part two, ‘An Angel at my Table’, is an account of her disturbing experiences after being committed to an institution. In the final part, ‘The Envoy from Mirror City’, after an uneasy fellowship with Europe’s artistic-set, Janet returns to New Zealand conveying a sense of confidence and hope. Adapted by Laura Jones from the three volumes of Frame’s autobiography. Starring Kerry Fox, Alexia Keogh and Karen Fergusson. Cinematography by Stuart Dryburgh.

results.title: Angel
results.creator_credit: Sharyn Prentice, Open Channel Productions and Dennis K. Smith
results.brief_description: You may not know the name Deborah Halpern, but you will certainly recognise her ceramic sculpture with its unique tiling located out the front of the National Gallery of Victoria. Hers is the story of a young ceramic sculptor with no formal training whose public profile has proliferated as the result of an unexpected major commission from one of Australia’s most prestigious art galleries. Deborah Haplpern’s art is inspired by Niki de Phalle, the ‘Art Brut’ movement and the ‘Outsider’ artists of Europe who live and work outside the mainstream gallery system. In this documentary Deborah talks intimately about the influence of these artists on her work and life. It outlines the structure of her sculpture, Angel, as well as the artistic and intellectual processes and motivation behind her work. This is a story of achievement. It is a passionate account of a two year project, the journey of a young artist and her triumphant arrival into the public art forum.

results.title: Angel
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Guy Glover and Derek May
results.brief_description: High contrast film stock is used to give a silhouette effect. Music is by Leonard Cohen. This is a film about a young man, a girl and a dog in which the visuals are over exposed. The girl tries to fly with wings which are more symbolic than practical and the dog and young man make similar attempts. This film won awards at Columbus, Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver.

results.title: Andy Warhol: the complete picture
results.creator_credit: Bravo Network, Channel Four, Fenton Bailey, Randy Barbato and Chris Radley
results.brief_description: Fascinating documentary about the life and work of one of the twentieth century’s most influential artists - Andy Warhol. Originally born Andrew Warhola to immigrant Slovakian parents, this tale starts with a history of his family life in Pittsburgh and travails his life’s work up to his death in 1987. Not unlike his films, the vision lingers on the exteriors of buildings, the beauty of the everyday through signs and architecture set against a moving sky. The facts are rendered easily to memory as the images are beautiful to watch and the narration by Julian Rhind-Tutt engaging. The only American artist to have a museum dedicated to him, Warhol’s obsessive behaviour in documenting his life (over 600 time capsules were created by the artist) fills the museum. His audio-tapes, art, magazine publishing, band and other enterprises are discussed through interviews with friends, family and fans and demonstrated by an elegant assemblage of photos and ephemera.

results.title: Andy Warhol: made in China
results.creator_credit: Lee Caplin Productions and Lee Evan Caplin
results.brief_description: This is a short documentary film, purportedly to be the last film of Andy Warhol before he died, which combines an insight into the world of Andy Warhol along with a travelogue of Hong Kong and China. Alfred Sui, an American educated Chinese who has lived in Hong Kong for twenty years, created the “I Club”, a glitzy disco nightclub located in the heart of Hong Kong’s financial district in the Bank of America building and fashioned in the western style of the New York nightclubs. The “I Club” represented modern western architecture and design and featured paintings by world renowned artists, including many of Andy Warhol’s work. Alfred Sui invited Andy Warhol and his entourage to open his new night club in 1985 which was to be patronised by the wealthy and famous, who wish to see and be seen. In the following days after the opening, Andy becomes a tourist visiting Peking, the Great Wall of China, Red Square but all the time comparing eastern culture with western culture and appearing to be mildly disappointed in the lack of westernization in China (no McDonalds!). Andy’s egocentricity also begins to surface as he realises that the Chinese really do not know who Andy Warhol is, that it is only American tourists who recognise him and want to take his photo. A strange but interesting doco with rare footage of a relaxed and open Andy Warhol.

results.title: Andy Warhol and His Work
results.brief_description: This film is a fascinating insight into the man and his work as seen through his own eyes and those of his friends. As the sixties progressed Warhol became more and more involved in film making. A number of his films are classic examples of underground movie making and are valid reflections of the more extreme ends of life in late-sixties America.

results.title: Andy Warhol
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Andy Warhol was born Andrew Warhola in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 1928. Upon graduation from Carnegie Institute of Technology, he moved to New York and began working as a commercial artist where his success in graphic arts and illustration was celebrated. This documentary begins with his early commercial work and follows his career over 20 years until his death in 1987. Contains interviews with cast members from Warhol’s films “Sleep” and “Chelsea Girls”.

results.title: Andy Hardy Series
results.brief_description: One of the most popular US series, the Hardy family first appeared in “A Family Affair” 1937 with Lionel Barrymore and Mickey Rooney as father and son. In 1938 “You’re Only Young Once” began the official series in the town of Carvel, with Rooney as Andy Hardy, typical American teenager, interested in girls and fast cars, Lewis Stone as James Judge Hardy, a stern but understanding father, Fay Holden as his “swell” mother, Cecilia Parker as Marian, his older sister striving to be a young lady, Sara Haden as Aunt Millie and Ann Rutherford as Polly, the girlfriend who was often neglected for other prospects but to whom Andy always returned. George B. Seitz directed most of the series. A testament to the series’ great appeal was the special Oscar given MGM “for its achievement in representing the American Way of Life.” MGM used the films to springboard young starlets such as Judy Garland, Lana Turner, Esther Williams, Kathryn Grayson and Donna Reed. The Hardy films serve as a reminder of an era in Hollywood and America that is long gone.

results.title: Andy Hardy meets debutante
results.creator_credit: George B. Seitz, Loews Incorporated and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Andy Hardy Series”.
Andy (Mickey Rooney) is dazzled by a picture in a magazine of a glamorous debutante (Diana Lewis). When Judge Hardy’s (Lewis Stone) crusade to save an orphanage takes him to New York City, Andy joins him in the hope of meeting his dream girl. However, the Big Apple shows little sympathy for a cocky, small town boy and his hairbrained schemes to break into high society backfire with disastrous but humerous results. Finally, his old pal Betsy Booth (Judy Garland), a high society girl herself, lends Andy a hand - and a tuxedo. This is one of the most entertaining films in the series and features Judy Garland performing “Alone” and “I’m Nobody’s Baby.”

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Andy Hardy Series”.
Mickey Rooney is lovable as the evervescent teenager Andy with the stern judge father and understanding mother. Andy is about to graduate from high school and gets an inflated opinion of himself. He hires a social secretary played by Kathryn Grayson to sort out his complicated domestic affairs. Grayson does a superb rendition of Strauss’ “Voices of Spring.”
